data.meta_description: Russian rulers of the 1500s AD: Ivan the Great, Vasili, his widow Elena Glinskaya, their son Ivan the Terrible. He tried to help the poor against the rich.
data.text:
Ivan the Great

When Ivan the Great, the first Czar of Russia, died in 1505 AD, he left Russia just beginning to be an important power in Central Asia.

Who was Ivan the Great?

Late Medieval timeline

All our Central Asia articles

Vasili

Ivanâ€™s son Vasili, who succeeded him when he was 26 years old, conquered even more of Lithuania. In 1526, Vasili divorced his wife and remarried against the wishes of the Orthodox church. (It was in the same year that Henry VIII in England began struggling with Church approval of his divorce; perhaps he had heard of the Russian decision?) But in the end Vasili was able to remarry without losing the support of the bishops.

Who was Henry VIII?

What is a bishop?

Elena Glinskaya

Vasili died in 1533 at the age of 54, and his wife Elena (originally from Serbia) ruled for the next five years as regent for their 3-year-old son Ivan. Elena was 23 years old when she got power. Maybe it helped that Hurrem Sultan was so powerful in the Ottoman Empire to her south.

Who was Hurrem Sultan?

History of money

In 1535, Elena created a unified money system for Russia. She also negotiated treaties with Lithuania and with Sweden. But in 1538 Elena died. She may have been poisoned by the Russian lords. Then those lords took over as regents for poor little Ivan.

Ivan the Terrible

When Ivan turned sixteen and took power, he was a strong and ambitious czar like his grandfather Ivan (even though he looks a little frightened in the picture!). Rich people in Russia hated Ivan, because he killed many lords in order to get all the power for himself. They called him Ivan the Terrible.

What is Islam?

But Ivan ran Russia well: he wrote new laws and created a representative council. He made the Church less powerful. Ivan also expanded Russia to the east into Siberia, conquering Muslim people and making Russia into a combined Christian-Muslim country.

Michael Romanov

But after Ivan died in 1584, his son died with no children, leaving Russia weaker. The continued Little Ice Age caused famines and made things worse.

The Little Ice Age

Poland got more and more power over Russia. Finally in 1613 things began to get better: the Russians fought off the Polish army and a national assembly elected Michael Romanov to be the new Czar.
